conclusion: The coil is a square with side length L and has N turns. The coil rotates with an angular velocity Ï‰ in a uniform magnetic field B. The axis of rotation OO' is perpendicular to the magnetic field and coplanar with the coil.

premise: The induced EMF in a rotating coil is given by: ε = -N dΦ/dt where Φ is the magnetic flux through the coil.
conclusion: The magnetic flux Φ is: Φ = B · A · cos(θ)
A = L^2 is the area of the coil.
θ is the angle between the normal to the coil and the magnetic field.

premise: The maximum EMF occurs when dΦ/dt is at its maximum, which happens when θ = 0 or θ = π.
conclusion: The angle θ changes with time as θ = ωt.
The flux as a function of time is: Φ(t) = B · L^2 · cos(ωt)
Differentiating with respect to time: dΦ/dt = -B · L^2 · ω · sin(ωt)
The maximum value of sin(ωt) is 1, so the maximum induced EMF is: ε_max = N · B · L^2 · ω
The root mean square (RMS) or effective value of the EMF is given by: ε_rms = ε_max/√2
